content: The "Medicaid Reform and Personal Responsibility Act of 2017" requires states to implement a work requirement for able-bodied adults without dependents under Medicaid. The "Medicaid Reform and Personal Responsibility Act of 2017" mandates states to enforce a work requirement for able-bodied adults without dependents in Medicaid, as outlined in Section 1902 of the Social Security Act. The "Medicaid Reform and Personal Responsibility Act of 2017" requires states to implement a work requirement for able-bodied adults without dependents in Medicaid. An able-bodied adult without dependents is defined as an individual who is not under 18 or over 55 years of age, not medically unfit for employment, not a parent or caregiver of a dependent child, and not a pregnant woman. The "Medicaid Reform and Personal Responsibility Act of 2017" mandates a work requirement for able-bodied adults without dependents in Medicaid. This includes individuals who are not minors or seniors, not medically unable to work, not caregivers, and not pregnant women. The work requirement involves participating in state-specified work activities for at least 20 hours per week on average. The "Medicaid Reform and Personal Responsibility Act of 2017" mandates work requirements for able-bodied adults without dependents in Medicaid. This includes on-the-job training, job skills training, and community service programs. Able-bodied adults without dependents must register as employed or actively looking for employment every 12 months and satisfy applicable work requirements to receive medical assistance under this title. The Medicaid Reform and Personal Responsibility Act of 2017 mandates work requirements for able-bodied adults without dependents in Medicaid. This includes accepting job offers at a wage not less than the applicable Federal or State minimum wage or 80% of the wage that would have been applicable under the Fair Labor Standards Act. Refusal to provide sufficient information to the State for determining employment status or job availability without good cause is also grounds for non-compliance. The Medicaid Reform and Personal Responsibility Act of 2017 mandates work requirements for able-bodied adults without dependents in Medicaid, including accepting job offers at a minimum wage. Non-compliance includes refusal to provide information for determining job availability or voluntarily quitting a job without good cause.
